Dear Mr. Mulvany:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Discipline
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10169
Section (1) A facility shall have and follow written policy and procedure
Description which stipulates that residents shall not be subjected to any of the
following:
(a) Corporal or cruel punishment.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was punched during an altercation with staff.
Investigation Face-to-face contact was made with Supervisor 1 on 04/05/2024
at the facility during an announced visit. The area where the
alleged incident occurred was viewed and documentation was
provided.
The Complainant was interviewed on 04/05/2024.
The Chief Administrator was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1
during an announced face-to-face visit on 04/05/2024. He stated
he had reviewed the video footage of the incident and had
debriefed it with both staff and youth in the resulting days.
Policies & procedures as well as video footage was provided for
this investigation.
Youth A was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
announced face-to-face visit on 04/05/2024. Youth A described
the incident in question as starting with him being on a phone call
with a family member and Staff 1 was supervising. Youth A stated
he got upset, but did not clarify specifically why, and he started
breaking things in the side office room where he had taken the
phone call. Youth A stated staff asked him to go to his room and
he refused. Youth A recalled stating to staff that they “better let
him slit his wrists.” Youth A believed this was when staff members
attempted to restrain him while he was still in that same side office
room. The staff members he recalled being involved were Staff
1, Staff 2 and Staff 3. Youth A believed these staff members
picked him up and they then left that side room to the common
area of the unit. Youth A stated the staff members were about to
put him in his room when he grabbed onto the hair of Staff 2 with
both hands and started pulling. Youth A recalled using a great
deal of force when doing this. Youth A remembered Staff 1
2

punching him in his side when this occurred. He also recalled one
of the staff members attempted to peel back his hands from the
hair of Staff 2 prior to him being punched. Youth A believed he
had his hands on the hair of Staff 2 for about five minutes. Youth
A recalled letting go of her hair as he was near the entrance to his
room. Youth A stated he then attempted to pull the hair of Staff 1
but was unsuccessful. At this point Youth A then was inside of his
room and he tried to rush back out, only for staff members to stop
him. Youth A stated the staff were then able to close the door to
his room. Youth A believed no one else saw this incident because
all of the youth were already in their rooms. He stated this was a
common practice when he got very upset and fought staff.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
announced, face-to-face visit on 04/05/2024. He was not a
witness to the incident. He stated he has worked with Staff 1 for a
long time and has never had any concerns with his approach to
the youth, both in terms of verbal de-escalation or instances
where physical intervention is necessary.
Staff 1 was interviewed with DHHS Worker 1 during an
announced, face-to-face visit on 04/05/2024. Staff 1 stated that
he was working with Youth A on the date in question, when Youth
A began to escalate at the end of a phone call with a family
member. Staff 1 recalled being present with Staff 3 as Youth A
escalated first verbally, then physically as he began to break items
within the room where the phone call occurred. Staff 1 recalled
that Staff 2 received approval from management for them to
attempt to restraint Youth A after he broke a vase. Staff 1
explained the history of Youth A’s attempts at self harm as the
reasoning to attempt a restraint. Staff 1 stated the restraint
attempt was difficult in the small space and Youth A fought back
immediately, resulting in he and Staff 3 attempting to remove
Youth A from the room to a more open space in the common area
of the unit. Staff 1 stated Staff 2 eventually became involved in
the restraint attempt and in doing so, Youth A grabbed on to Staff
2’s hair and began pulling it forcefully. Staff 1 stated he attempted
the approved method of trying to pull Youth A’s fingers back to
force him to release Staff 2’s hair but this was not effective. Staff
1 recalled hearing Staff 2 yell in pain. Staff 1 stated he then chose
to punch Youth A in the side in an attempt to distract Youth A and
hopefully get him to release Staff 2’s hair. Staff 1 stated this did
not have an effect either. Staff 1 stated he eventually was able to
use his own hands to get Youth A to release Staff 2’s hair. Staff 1
confirmed the physical nature of the incident ended when they
were able to have Youth A stay in his room. Staff 1 re-iterated
3

that he attempted the approved and trained maneuvers to try to
get Youth A to release Staff 2’s hair and because of her reaction
to Youth A, he made a split second decision to try something else
and punch Youth A. Staff 1 also confirmed that punching is not a
method that is approved for physical intervention by the facility.
Staff 1 stated it was possible that they could have attempted to
transition the restraint to the ground in a safe and approved
manner, but that did not occur during the intense situation.
Staff 2 was interviewed over the phone on 05/30/2024. She
recalled that Youth A was acting “off” the evening of the incident
but Staff 2 made sure he got his phone call in with his mother.
Staff 2 recalled Youth A getting upset at the end of the call and he
began to wrap his shirt around his neck in a loose manner. Youth
A also began speaking very aggressively to the staff nearby.
Youth A then began to destroy property within the small office he
was in and then created an unsafe environment to the point that a
restraint attempt was warranted. Staff 1 and Staff 3 then
attempted a standing restraint with Youth A and Staff 2 recalled
this quickly escalated to all three individuals moving out of the
small room to the unit common area with Youth A struggling
against the restraint. As the struggle continued, Staff 2 attempted
to assist in the restraint, and this was when Youth A was able to
get a hand free and grab Staff 2 by the hair. She recalled him
pulling on her head with force and it caused a great deal of pain.
Staff 2 recalled his hand was able to be taken off of her head after
approximately two minutes. Staff 2 could not recall exactly how
Staff 1 and Staff 3 were trying to assist her in getting Youth A’s
hand off of her head.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 06/04/2024. He
recalled Youth A participating in a family phone call on the night in
question. Staff 3 remembered Youth A ended his phone call and
then began to escalate physically, including slamming a vase to
the ground and causing many sharp pieces to scatter. Staff 3
recalled initiating a restraint of Youth A with Staff 1. Staff 3
believed that, because of Youth A’s struggling, they moved out of
the smaller room and into the common area of the unit. At some
point Staff 2 became involved and tried to help them and this was
when Youth A got his hands on her hair. Staff 3 recalled
witnessing Staff 2’s hair be pulled aggressively, and he attempted
to pull Youth A’s hands off of her hair. Staff 2 recalled attempting
to pry Youth A’s thumbs back as they are trained to do. He could
not recall specifically how but did remember that Youth A
eventually let go of Staff 2’s hair in the process of being placed
4

inside of his room. Staff 2 did not recall seeing Staff 1 punch
Youth A in the side.
During a video call on 05/03/2024 DHHS Worker 1 stated that
there would not be a confirmed case as a result of his
investigation.
Video Review:
Video footage of the incident from 04/01/2024 was reviewed on
04/11/2024. The footage began at 7:50 pm on 04/01/2024. It
showed Youth A as he was in the smaller side room of the unit
where phone calls occur. Youth A was seen already escalated,
with his shirt off and destroying property. Staff 1 and Staff 3
attempted to perform a standing restraint and Youth A resisted,
causing all three to move forward toward the door to the small
room. The two staff are joined by Staff 2 as they attempt to
remove Youth A from the room. The four individuals then moved
into the common area of the unit as there was a continued
struggle. At 7:50:35 pm it was seen that Youth A had both hands
on the hair of Staff 2. Staff 1 then struck Youth A in his left side
with his right fist one time. The video footage continued and
showed the continued struggle until Youth A was able to be
placed in his room at 7:51:55pm.
Documents reviewed:
• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 1 completed the required restraint model training
on 10/25/2023.
• Facility policy titled “Emergency and Safety Management”
was provided and reviewed. In this policy a section titled
“Restraints” outlined the practices of the facility when
physical management of a youth was deemed necessary.
It described factors requiring the hands on intervention with
youth that were consistent with the reasoning for the
restraint attempted with Youth A during the incident in
question.
• Training materials for the chosen approved restraint model,
Management of Aggressive Behavior (MOAB) were
provided and reviewed. It was noted there are no approved
methods of physical management that include striking a
youth.
• Incident report dated 04/01/2024 was consistent with Youth
A’s and Staff 1’s interview.
• Documentation from the facility titled “Corrective Action
Plan - Staff Incident” dated 04/19/2024 was provided and
reviewed. In this documentation the Chief Administrator
5

discussed a review of the incident with Staff 1 and how
further training and support could be offered to prevent the
specific action of striking Youth A from occurring in a similar
incident in the future.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance due to Staff 1 striking
Youth A during the incident, per video review and interviews.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
